metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (automatic weather station of Huazhaizi desert steppe station, 2020)
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from the automatic weather station (AWS) at the observation system of Meteorological elements gradient of Huazhaizi desert steppe station from January 1 to December 31, 2020. The site (100.3201°E, 38.7659°N) was located on a desert steppe surface in the Huazhaizi, which is near Zhangye city, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1731 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (HMP45AC; 5 and 10 m, north), wind speed and direction profile (windsonic; 5 and 10 m, north), air pressure (CS100; 2 m), rain gauge (TE525M; 10 m), four-component radiometer (CNR1; 6 m, south), two infrared temperature sensors (SI-111; 6 m, south, vertically downward), soil heat flux (HFP01; 3 duplicates, -0.06 m), soil temperature profile (109ss-L; 0, -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.6, -1.0 m), soil moisture profile (ML3; -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.6, -1.0 m).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_5 m and Ta_10 m; RH_5 m and RH_10 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_5 m and Ws_10 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_5 m and WD_10 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, and Gs_3) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_60 cm, Ts_100 cm) (℃), soil moisture (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm, Ms_10 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_60 cm, Ms_100 cm) (%).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The missing data were denoted by -6999. Due to the malfunction of sensors, data during 1.14-1.17 and 5.11-5.16 were missing; (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2020-6-10 10:30. (6) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What are 'hydrometeorological data' in the context of oasis–desert systems?
Definition.Answer: In the context of oasis–desert systems, 'hydrometeorological data' refer to observations related to radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles. These data are typically collected from automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period.

Definition.Question: What does 'eddy covariance system' mean in the context of data collection methods?
Definition.Answer: An 'eddy covariance system' is a data collection method that involves acquiring half-hourly turbulent flux data, particularly for energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes. This system is used to measure and analyze exchanges between the surface and the atmosphere over oasis–desert systems.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'data processing and quality control procedure' in the context of observational datasets?
Definition.Answer: In the context of observational datasets, 'data processing and quality control procedure' refers to the steps taken to ensure the accuracy and reliability of data, which include data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing. These procedures are crucial for maintaining the integrity of datasets related to energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems.

Comparison.Question: How does the data collection method of using automatic weather stations in oasis-desert areas compare to the use of eddy covariance systems in terms of capturing energy and water vapor fluxes?
Comparison.Answer: Automatic weather stations, as used in the field above, provide hydrometeorological data like radiation and soil temperature profiles with a 10-minute average period. In contrast, eddy covariance systems capture half-hourly turbulent flux data, which include energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, offering more direct measurements of these fluxes compared to the averaged data from weather stations.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data processing and quality control techniques between datasets collected in the Heihe River Basin and those from other inland river basins facing ecological degradation?
Comparison.Answer: In the Heihe River Basin, data processing involves ensuring a certain number of data points per day, marking missing data, and removing erroneous or duplicate data. This systematic approach might differ from other basins where data processing could vary based on specific regional challenges such as more frequent dust storms or differing vegetation types, impacting the kind of errors or data loss encountered.

Comparison.Question: How do the challenges of maintaining ecological balance in oasis-desert systems compare with those in other arid inland river basins, such as the Tarim River basin?
Comparison.Answer: Both oasis-desert systems and other arid inland river basins face challenges like river drying and land desertification. However, oasis-desert systems are unique in that they play a crucial role in supporting a majority of the population in arid regions, which adds socio-economic pressure to maintain ecological stability. This contrasts with other basins where the focus might be more on ecological impacts rather than immediate socio-economic dependencies.

Interpretation.Question: How do the observed long-term patterns in air temperature and soil moisture data from meteorological stations inform us about the interactions between oasis and desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: The observed long-term patterns in air temperature and soil moisture data can provide insights into the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange dynamics in oasis–desert ecosystems. These patterns help researchers understand the balance required for sustainable oasis development and the ecological stability of these regions.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise in collecting continuous and accurate data in arid inland river basins, and how can these be mitigated?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in data collection in arid inland river basins include ecological degradation, such as drying rivers and intensified desertification. These can be mitigated by using robust quality control methods, such as ensuring data completeness, removing erroneous data, and maintaining consistent data formats.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do errors occur in the data collected from automatic weather stations, particularly in the context of oasis–desert systems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Errors in data collection from automatic weather stations can occur due to sensor malfunctions, environmental interference, and extreme weather conditions that are prevalent in oasis–desert systems, which can disrupt the accuracy and reliability of the measurements.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the complexity of understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The complexity arises from the intricate interactions between the diverse ecological components of oasis–desert ecosystems, including varying soil moisture levels, vegetation types, atmospheric conditions, and the unique balance between oasis and desert areas, all of which require comprehensive long-term observations to accurately assess their energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of utilizing automatic weather stations for data collection in oasis-desert ecosystems on the understanding of climate interactions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing automatic weather stations for data collection in oasis-desert ecosystems allows for continuous and precise monitoring of climate interactions, including energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges. This can significantly enhance the understanding of these interactions, contributing to the recognition of oasis-desert dynamics and aiding in the ecological stability and sustainable development of oases.

Causal Consequence.Question: What outcomes can be expected from long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis-desert systems regarding ecological and socioeconomic development?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis-desert systems can lead to improved understanding of ecological dynamics and contribute to the goal of sustainable oasis development. These observations are crucial for maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems, supporting ecological security, and promoting socioeconomic development by providing data-driven insights for policy and management strategies.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of collecting meteorological and soil parameter data in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives include understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems to support ecological security and sustainable development. This understanding is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and achieving goals such as carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in these regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended outcomes of establishing multiple land surface flux and meteorological stations in the arid regions of western China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended outcomes include collecting comprehensive datasets of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations. These datasets aim to provide critical insights into the interactions within oasis–desert areas, which can significantly affect the carbon balance and contribute to global carbon cycle understanding, thereby supporting the ecological environment and economic development in these regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in ensuring the quality control of meteorological data collected in arid regions, especially when dealing with erroneous values from sensors?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data processing and quality control procedures include ensuring that each day has 144 data entries (one every 10 minutes), marking missing data with -6999, removing duplicate records, deleting data that are beyond physical significance or instrument range, marking questionable data in red, and standardizing the date and time format.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the key steps in the data collection and archiving process for long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange datasets in oasis–desert systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data collection process involves acquiring half-hourly turbulent flux data using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer, alongside hydrometeorological data every 10 minutes from automatic weather stations. This data is then processed, archived, and shared, with vegetation and soil parameters supplemented in the datasets.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the comprehensive monitoring of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: A suite of observational datasets comprising long-term energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, enable comprehensive monitoring. Data is acquired using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers, with additional hydrometeorological data collected from automatic weather stations set to a 10-minute average period.

Enablement.Question: What technological systems are crucial for enabling long-term data collection in harsh, arid environments such as oasis-desert systems?
Enablement.Answer: Automatic weather stations with sensors measuring various meteorological and soil parameters are crucial for long-term data collection in these environments. These stations collect data on air temperature, humidity, wind speed, direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles, contributing to the understanding of ecological and meteorological dynamics in oasis-desert systems.

Enablement.Question: How do data processing and quality control methods enable the reliability and accuracy of datasets collected in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The data processing and quality control methods, which include ensuring consistent data collection, removing erroneous values, and standardizing data formats, enable the reliability and accuracy of datasets. Steps such as marking missing data, removing duplicate records, and eliminating physically implausible measurements are essential for maintaining the integrity of datasets collected in challenging environments.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be difficulties in ensuring the quality and completeness of data collected from automatic weather stations in arid and semi-arid regions?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges such as sensor errors, data loss, and environmental degradation in arid and semi-arid regions can affect data quality. The metadata notes issues like sensor errors causing incorrect wind speed and direction values, and missing data is marked with placeholders, indicating potential gaps or inaccuracies in the dataset.

Expectation.Question: Why could long-term observational data be crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Expectation.Answer: Long-term observations are indispensable for achieving a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, which is significant for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and maintaining ecological stability and socioeconomic development in arid regions, as stated in the relevant papers.

Expectation.Question: What reasons could there be for the emphasis on collecting auxiliary data involving vegetation and soil parameters alongside hydrometeorological data in oasis–desert systems?
Expectation.Answer: Including auxiliary data such as vegetation and soil parameters enhances the dataset's comprehensiveness, allowing for a more detailed analysis of the interactions within oasis–desert ecosystems, which is crucial for understanding the ecological balance and supporting sustainable development in these areas.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the major challenges faced in collecting long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert systems, and how might these be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: Major challenges in collecting long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert systems include ecological degradation such as river and lake drying and land desertification. Addressing these challenges requires maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems through sustainable development practices and proper data collection techniques.

Judgmental.Question: What is your assessment of the current state of available datasets for studying energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas, and what improvements could be made?
Judgmental.Answer: The available datasets provide valuable insights into energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas, particularly with the establishment of multiple land surface flux and meteorological stations. However, improvements could be made by expanding the temporal and spatial coverage of datasets and incorporating additional environmental parameters to enhance the understanding of oasis–desert interactions.

Assertion.Answer: The data quality control involves ensuring a consistent number of data points daily, marking missing data with specific indicators, removing duplicate records and out-of-range values, and using uniform date and time formats. Special attention is given to sensor-related errors and marking questionable data distinctly.

Assertion.Answer: Challenges include ecological degradation issues such as drying rivers, vegetation loss, land desertification, and dust storms, which are prevalent in arid inland river basins. These environmental conditions can impact the stability and reliability of data collection.

Assertion.Answer: Datasets from oasis–desert systems typically include long-term measurements of energy, water vapor, and carbon and methane fluxes, as well as supplementary hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameter data. They are structured to include half-hourly and average period data and are shared through platforms like the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the data collection methods used for observing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert areas, focusing on the sensors and instruments deployed.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods for observing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert areas include using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer for acquiring half-hourly turbulent flux data. Automatic weather stations provide hydrometeorological data such as radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, air temperature and humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles, with a 10-minute average period.

Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for studying oasis-desert interactions include long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, along with auxiliary hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters data from 2012 to 2021. These datasets are available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center and comprise data collected from 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations in the arid regions of western China.
